Progress Note
Adva Eisenberg, MD at 08/28/25 1428
NOVANT ENDOCRIONLOGY
REASON FOR VIST: Hypothyroidism
History of Present Illness
The patient is a 42 year old female who presents for evaluation of her
thyroid.
She was actually initially diagnosed with Graves' disease in 2018, confirmed
by findings on uptake/scan as well as positive TSI. She was also diagnosed
with Graves' eye disease, although there were conflicting opinions between
her eye doctor (Dr. Donald Stewart) her other providers about whether all
her findings were due to Graves' disease. She has not seen Dr. Stewart in
~2 years and has been told he is retiring. She never received specific
treatment for her Graves' disease and thyroid levels subsequently
normalized, though notably was started on Methotrexate for arthritis around
this time as well. Notably she had also been placed on Lithium about 18
months prior, though was only on it temporarily.
She experiences constant pressure in her right eye, which she believes is
due to increased exposure to dirt and irritants. She also reports pulsatile
tinnitus and a whooshing sensation in her ears, which started after a CT
scan in 01/2025
Her thyroid function tests have consistently shown elevated TPO antibodies,
and earlier this year she had 2 elevated TSH levels in a row, but has not
started thyroid hormone replacement.
This has exacerbated the pressure in her head and eye. She reports
irregular body temperature regulation, often feeling overheated and
experiencing rashes. She also reports both constipation and diarrhea, and
irregular digestion. Her periods are regular now, although they were not
during her adolescence. She has gained 30 pounds in 3 months, which she
attributes to being bedridden due to arm issues. She has been almost
bedridden due to arm issues, which limit her mobility to 1 or 2 hours a day.
She experiences hair loss in certain areas and has had a staph infection on
her face for 5 years, which has spread to her body. She has very dry and
irritable skin.
She was recently diagnosed with hypermobile EDS a year ago. The mast
cell issues started in 01/2025 after a bad reaction to a contrast dye. She
https://my.atriumhealth.org/myatriumhealth/Visits 1/5

She has a history of hyperthyroidism in her family, with several cousins

4/6/18 NM uptake/scan:
Narrative & Impression
Radiopharmaceuticals: 6 uCi of I-131 sodium iodide by mouth and 10.4 mCi
of Tc 99m Pertechnetate intravenously.
Radioiodine uptake: The 24-hour uptake is calculated at 65% (normal 10 to
30%).
Thyroid imaging: The thyroid gland is mildly enlarged. There is
homogeneous hyperactivity in both lobes, left slightly greater than right, with
no dominant hot or cold nodules.
IMPRESSION:
1. Graves' disease.
2/25/18 MRI Orbits:
Multisequence, multiplanar images were performed on a high field MRI
through the orbits before and after the uneventful ministration of 6 cc
Gadavist IV.
There is slight orbital asymmetry with the right globe protruding further than
the left. I see no intra or extraconal mass lesion to account for this, and the
orbital fat is preserved. The extraocular muscles are unremarkable. Slight
asymmetric inward
bowing of the left medial orbital wall suggests a possible remote left orbital
injury. There is also opacification of a left posterior ethmoid cell with
opacification of adjacent portions of a septated left sphenoid cell. Mild
mucosal thickening is seen
elsewhere within the ethmoids. No fluid level.
The visualized intracranial structures are unremarkable.
IMPRESSION: Orbital asymmetry as described. No definite orbital mass
lesion on the right. Question mild old medial orbital wall injury on the left.
Left sphenoethmoidal opacification also noted

9/3/25, 2:34 AM MyChart - Past Visit Details
Assessment & Plan
1. Hypothyroidism.
- Her last few TSH levels were elevated, indicating hypothyroidism. The
TPO antibody has been consistently positive, suggesting a shift from
Graves' disease to Hashimoto's over time. Lithium can trigger thyroid
immune disorders and may have contributed to her initial presentation.
- Levothyroxine will be prescribed with final dose TBD pending repeat TSH
today. The generic formulation will be tried first due to cost considerations. If
she experiences any reactions, she can message via MyChart and an
alternate formulation such as Tirosint can be tried
- A new baseline TSH level will be obtained before deciding on the
levothyroxine dosage. The results will be shared via MyChart. A lab recheck
will be scheduled in about 6 weeks to assess the effectiveness of the
starting dose.
2. Thyroid eye disease.
- She reports persistent swelling in her right eye, which may be related to
her thyroid condition.
- A referral to Dr. Pietraszkiewicz will be made for further evaluation of her
eye condition, and TSH and TRAb levels will be assessed today
Follow-up: 6-week lab-only visit and a 6-month office visit.

pulsitile tinnitus, Pulsatile tinnitus, right ear

No Comparison.
TECHNIQUE:
CT angiogram of the neck was performed following intravenous administration of contrast.
Helical axial images were obtained from the aortic arch to the skull base. 2D MIP and 3D
reformatted images were generated.
Degree of carotid stenosis is calculated by comparing the diameter of the maximum stenosis to
the diameter of the distal normal carotid artery using NASCET criteria.
CONTRAST:
65 cc of Omnipaque 350
FINDINGS:
Three-vessel branching pattern of the aortic arch. Origins of the common carotid arteries and
vertebral arteries are patent.
Common carotid arteries and carotid bulbs are patent. Cervical segments of the internal carotid
arteries are patent. No stenosis by NASCET criteria.
Cervical segments of the vertebral arteries are patent.
No abnormal vasculature in the region of the temporal bones.
Included lung apices are clear. C4-C6 ACDF.

History of Present Illness

has not yet identified the cause. A blocked lymph node in her armpit led to significant
swelling in her breast. She has been managing this with lymphatic drainage massage
therapy, which she performed two nights ago. She has not taken steroids for several years
and is seeking a temporary boost in energy to manage household tasks. Advised by her
patient advocate to consult her primary care physician regarding the potential use of
steroids. Awaiting the results of a test for chronic urticaria.
An appointment with a cardiologist is scheduled for 05/17/2025 due to persistent blood
pooling in her arms and legs. Describes a sensation of slushy blood when moving up and
down. This is the first time being bedridden in two weeks due to difficulty sitting up.
Continues to experience numbness and claw-like finger positioning, attributed to a tight
blood vessel extending down her arm. Experiences constant pain and has noticed
increased ambidexterity due to decreased use of her right arm. An ultrasound of her right
arm did not reveal any DVT, but questions the thoroughness of the analysis for possibility
of thoracic outlet syndrome. Reports frequent coldness in her arm and vein-centered pain.
Scheduled to meet with her patient advocate on Saturday to explore bracing and support
options for her shoulder.
A history of gastrointestinal issues includes lymphocytic colitis and ischemic colitis, both
diagnosed in her 20s. Does not have regular bowel movements and primarily consumes
liquid foods due to fear of stomach pain. A history of bulimia spans 10 to 20 years. The
last gastroenterologist recommended an endoscopy and colonoscopy, but these were not
completed due to relocation. Reports swelling on the right side of her stomach, particularly
during allergy flares.

• Follow-up
HPI
History of Present Illness
The patient is a 42-year-old female presenting for medication refill. Due for physical labs and she is fasting
today
She experienced a severe allergic reaction following a CT scan with contrast dye, unprecedented as she
had no prior adverse effects. Symptoms began an hour after returning home, with immobility and
exacerbation of existing symptoms for 5 days. Initially suspected COVID-19 or hospital-acquired illness,
later considered MCAS associated with POTS and EDS. Self-treated with antihistamines (two Zyrtec, two
Pepcid, and Claritin daily) with effective results. Reports brain and body burning sensations, burning, itchy,
watery eyes, skin infections, flares, internal heat, and night sweats. Considering consultations with an
immunologist and allergist. Experiencing severe brain fog, fatigue, and cognitive impairment, bedridden for
2 weeks, unable to stay awake for more than 30 minutes to an hour despite Adderall. Suspects anaphylaxis
for 4-5 days. Switching insurance for nationwide coverage to see specialists. Considering low-dose
naltrexone. Noticed pain and swelling correlation, intrigued by MCAS. Symptoms started 6 months post-
back surgery. Suspects vascular issue in right shoulder, possibly thoracic outlet syndrome. Pain in shoulder
and right bicep for 6-8 months. Very flexible, can wrap hands behind head. Not eating today, drinking salt
tabs and electrolytes. History of anorexia may contribute to low sodium and blood volume issues.
Experiences nausea at thought or smell of food, considering Ensure for nutrition. Interested in seeing a
doctor for POTS and vascular blood flow. Finds salt helpful, experiences brain tingling after three salt tabs.
Hopeful for positive health progression.
Supplemental Information
Had pneumonia at age 23, told eardrum ruptured, now wonders if it was a CSF leak.
FAMILY HISTORY
- Family history of strokes
ALLERGIES
- Severe allergic reaction to CT scan with contrast dye
MEDICATIONS
- Zyrtec
- Pepcid
- Claritin
- Adderall

History of Present Illness
The patient is a 42-year-old female presenting for medication refill. Due for physical labs
and she is fasting today
She experienced a severe allergic reaction following a CT scan with contrast dye,
unprecedented as she had no prior adverse effects. Symptoms began an hour after
returning home, with immobility and exacerbation of existing symptoms for 5 days. Initially
suspected COVID-19 or hospital-acquired illness, later considered MCAS associated with
POTS and EDS. Self-treated with antihistamines (two Zyrtec, two Pepcid, and Claritin
daily) with effective results. Reports brain and body burning sensations, burning, itchy,
watery eyes, skin infections, flares, internal heat, and night sweats. Considering
consultations with an immunologist and allergist. Experiencing severe brain fog, fatigue,
and cognitive impairment, bedridden for 2 weeks, unable to stay awake for more than 30
minutes to an hour despite Adderall. Suspects anaphylaxis for 4-5 days. Switching
insurance for nationwide coverage to see specialists. Considering low-dose naltrexone.
Noticed pain and swelling correlation, intrigued by MCAS. Symptoms started 6 months
post-back surgery. Suspects vascular issue in right shoulder, possibly thoracic outlet
syndrome. Pain in shoulder and right bicep for 6-8 months. Very flexible, can wrap hands
behind head. Not eating today, drinking salt tabs and electrolytes. History of anorexia may
contribute to low sodium and blood volume issues. Experiences nausea at thought or
smell of food, considering Ensure for nutrition. Interested in seeing a doctor for POTS and
vascular blood flow. Finds salt helpful, experiences brain tingling after three salt tabs.
Hopeful for positive health progression.
Supplemental Information
Had pneumonia at age 23, told eardrum ruptured, now wonders if it was a CSF leak.
FAMILY HISTORY
- Family history of strokes

c-KIT Mutation, Liquid Tumor
Test Current Result and Flag Previous Result and Date Units Reference Interval
c-KIT Mutation Analysis Result 02
No c-KIT mutation was identified in the provided specimen of this
individual. Results should be interpreted in conjunction with clinical
and other laboratory findings for the most accurate interpretation.
Background: 02
c-KIT is a proto-oncogene that encodes a type III trans-membrane
tyrosine kinase. c-KIT and its ligand stem cell factor have a key
role in survival, proliferation, differentiation and functional
activation of hematopoietic progenitor cells. c-KIT mutations are
reported in nearly all systemic mastocytosis, 20-40% core binding
factor (CBF) acute myeloid leukemia (AML), and approximately 20% high
grade myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and MDS derived AML. c-KIT
mutation in AML confers increased risk of relapse and decreased
overall survival. Tyrosine kinase inhibitor, such as Imatinib, has
been evaluated to treat systemic mastocytosis and c-KIT positive AML
and MDS, and was found effective as single reagent or combination
therapy.
Methodology: 02
Genomic DNA was purified from the provided specimen. Exon 8 and 17 of
c-KIT gene coding were subjected to PCR amplification and
bi-directional sequencing in duplicate to identify sequence
variations. This assay has a sensitivity to detect approximately 10%
population of cells containing the c-KIT mutations in a background of
non-mutant cells. This assay will not detect the mutation below the
sensitivity of this assay. Molecular-based testing is highly accurate,
but as in any laboratory test, rare diagnostic errors may occur.
Reference: 02
1. Care RS. et al. (2003). Incidence and prognosis of c-KIT
and FLT3 mutations in core binding factor (CBF) acute
myeloid leukaemias. Br J Haematol 121(5):775-777.
2. Paschka P. et al. (2006). Adverse prognosis significance
of KIT mutations in adult acute myeloid leukemia with
inv(16) and t(8;21): A cancer and leukemia group B study.
J. Clin Oncology 24:3904-3911.
3. Gotlib J. et al. (2005). Activity of the tyrosine kinase
inhibitor PKC412 in a patient with mast cell leukemia
with the D816V KIT mutation. Blood 106(6):2865-2870.
4. Schittenhelm MM. et al. (2006). Dasatinib (BMS-354825), a
Dual SRC/ABL kinase inhibitor, inhibits the kinase
activity of wild-type, juxtamembrane, and activation

documents.fullText:
I wanted to medically document my latest flare as it was significant in
scale and very indicative of a new set of symptoms that are very
telling.
Tuesday December 31 2024 Day 1
AM CT Angiogram of Neck Area
Zero Complications with Scan
Symptoms onset within an hour of CT scan with contrast dye
Joint/Muscle Pain Neck Pain/Head too Heavy
Face & Head Flushing Head Pressure/Burning
Brain Fog Itchy/Watery Eyes
Tachycardia Labored Breathing
Shoulder Pain GI Pain/Issues
Extreme Fatigue Light Headedness/Vertigo
Severe onset of many multi-system symptoms causing extreme fatigue and brain fog
and all over pain. I noticed the pain first but I couldn’t sit up or stay awake very long
at all. I just stared at the wall unable to think or focus clearly, staying alert for an
hour max. It felt like there was a lot of pressure in my head.


I assumed I picked up COVID or another illness at the hospital and waited it out.
keyFindings: Symptoms onset within an hour of CT scan with contrast dye
Severe onset of many multi-system symptoms causing extreme fatigue and brain fog and all over pain

documents.fullText:
Monday January 6 2025 Day 7
AM 4AM - thought of MCAS & took hydrozozine
Symptoms became unbearable and the pressure in my head was really bad & I
remembered reading about the “trifecta” and research on EDS, POTS, and MCAS
and was still unaware of what MCAS was. I did one search and found contrast dye
could be a trigger for MCAS and out of curiosity and desperation I took an anti-
histamine. When I woke up a couple hours later, I felt significantly better.
NOON Started Noticing symptoms coming back
12:00 12:15 12:30
12:30 PM Took 1 Benadryl and symptoms subsided for 1 hour
Took 1 Hydrozozine and symptoms reduced for the
2:00 PM
rest of the evening
PM Took Zyrtec - felt most relief yet in hour
It was here I began to suspect that I had some type of MCAS
reaction to the contrast dye due to the histamines working so
well and based on research I have read on the three conditions
being related in many cases.

documents.fullText:
It seems that since I had the CT scan and my histamine reaction
to the contrast dye that it has taken 14 days to regain some
sense of feeling normal although the pressure in my head and the
feeling of my “head being too heavy to hold up and extreme brain
fog and fatigue have stuck around. I am taking anti-histamines
every 12 hours to try to reduce the histamine buildup in my body
but it seems the new normal is to have the histamine buildup &
that I am currently always trying to take enough anti-histamines
to keep it down
I personally have noticed that my MCAS/allergy symptoms seem
to flare not so much when I eat anything but more so based on
movement and physical exertion. Any attempt to do too much of
anything leads my face to immediately get flushed and feelings of
nausea, fatigue, dizziness, and intense intercranial pressure.
I often refer to my original main symptoms list from 2020 that is
below and although I am VERY surprised to learn histamine has
anything to do with all of this, I can see some of the symptoms
were there all along.
keyFindings: head being too heavy to hold up

Dear Dr. Pascarella
It was a pleasure to see JENNIFER CARTRETTE. See assessment and plan below for my recommendations.
Dr. Pascarella ­ UNC Vascular Surgeon
Dr. Narang ­ GI
Dr. Eisenberg ­ Endocrinology
Dr. Baker ­ Atrium Rheumatology
Dr. Falawee ­ Sanger Cardiology
ASSESSMENT:
Patient is a 42­year­old female with history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, EDS, POTS, cervical DDD, arthritis, fibromyalgia,
bulimia/anorexia, rheumatoid arthritis, polyarthralgia rheumatica, PTSD, psoriatic arthritis. She is following at UNC for thoracic outlet
obstruction with significant right shoulder pain.
She has been referred for MCAS. She has a myriad of symptoms and is undergoing evaluation for EDS, POTS, MCAS. My goal with
evaluation is to determine if she has systemic mastocytosis as contributing to her symptoms as a primary bone marrow disorder or if the
MCAS is secondary/reactive. We turned our discussion toward work​up of systemic mastocytosis. In systemic mastocytosis, tryptase
level is > 20, 70% of the time. There can be indolent and smoldering systemic mastocytosis. Signs and symptoms attributed to acute
and/or chronic mast cell mediator release or organ infiltration include flushing, pruritis, urticaria, usually with diffuse skin involvement. We
can also see nausea, vomiting, bloating, chronic diarrhea, GERD, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and fibromyalgia like diffuse MSK pain,
pain in long bones, osteopenia/osteoporosis, and pathologic fractures. From a Cardiovascular perspective, we can see hypotension,
tachycardia. You may not always seen evidence or changes in CBC or peripheral blood, though typically would see eosinophilia.
We can consider a bone marrow biopsy or punch biopsy of skin lesion at the time of flare to look for c­​kit mutation and tryptase staining
on the marrow, which would confirm a mast cell process driving her symptoms.
To diagnose systemic mastocytosis:
Major criterion: Multifocal dense infiltrates of mast cells (=15 mast cells in aggregates) detected in sections of bone marrow and/or other
extracutaneous organ(s).
Minor Criteria: need 3
1. In biopsy sections of bone marrow or other extracutaneous organs, >25% of the mast cells in the infiltrate are spindle ​shaped or have
atypical morphology or >25% of all mast cells in bone marrow aspirate smears are immature or atypical.
2. Detection of an activating point mutation at codon 816 of KIT in the bone marrow, blood, or another extracutaneous organ.
3. Mast cells in bone marrow, blood, or another extracutaneous organ express CD25, with or without CD2, in addition to normal mast
cell markers.
4. Serum total tryptase is persistently >20 ng/mL, unless there is an associated myeloid neoplasm, in which case this parameter is not
valid.
At this time, continue management of MCAS as directed.

Dear Dr. Pascarella
It was a pleasure to see JENNIFER CARTRETTE. See assessment and plan below for my recommendations.
Dr. Pascarella ­ UNC Vascular Surgeon
Dr. Narang ­ GI
Dr. Eisenberg ­ Endocrinology
Dr. Baker ­ Atrium Rheumatology
Dr. Falawee ­ Sanger Cardiology
ASSESSMENT:
Patient is a 42­year­old female with history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, EDS, POTS, cervical DDD, arthritis, fibromyalgia,
bulimia/anorexia, rheumatoid arthritis, polyarthralgia rheumatica, PTSD, psoriatic arthritis. She is following at UNC for thoracic outlet
obstruction with significant right shoulder pain.
She has been referred for MCAS. She has a myriad of symptoms and is undergoing evaluation for EDS, POTS, MCAS. My goal with
evaluation is to determine if she has systemic mastocytosis as contributing to her symptoms as a primary bone marrow disorder or if the
MCAS is secondary/reactive. We turned our discussion toward work​up of systemic mastocytosis. In systemic mastocytosis, tryptase
level is > 20, 70% of the time. There can be indolent and smoldering systemic mastocytosis. Signs and symptoms attributed to acute
and/or chronic mast cell mediator release or organ infiltration include flushing, pruritis, urticaria, usually with diffuse skin involvement. We
can also see nausea, vomiting, bloating, chronic diarrhea, GERD, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and fibromyalgia like diffuse MSK pain,
pain in long bones, osteopenia/osteoporosis, and pathologic fractures. From a Cardiovascular perspective, we can see hypotension,
tachycardia. You may not always seen evidence or changes in CBC or peripheral blood, though typically would see eosinophilia.
We can consider a bone marrow biopsy or punch biopsy of skin lesion at the time of flare to look for c­​kit mutation and tryptase staining
on the marrow, which would confirm a mast cell process driving her symptoms.
To diagnose systemic mastocytosis:
Major criterion: Multifocal dense infiltrates of mast cells (=15 mast cells in aggregates) detected in sections of bone marrow and/or other
extracutaneous organ(s).
Minor Criteria: need 3
1. In biopsy sections of bone marrow or other extracutaneous organs, >25% of the mast cells in the infiltrate are spindle ​shaped or have
atypical morphology or >25% of all mast cells in bone marrow aspirate smears are immature or atypical.
2. Detection of an activating point mutation at codon 816 of KIT in the bone marrow, blood, or another extracutaneous organ.
3. Mast cells in bone marrow, blood, or another extracutaneous organ express CD25, with or without CD2, in addition to normal mast
cell markers.
4. Serum total tryptase is persistently >20 ng/mL, unless there is an associated myeloid neoplasm, in which case this parameter is not
valid.
At this time, continue management of MCAS as directed.

checking tryptase once off of antihistamines x 4­5 days
also checking 24 hour n­methylhistamine in urine

ASSESSMENT:
Patient is a 42­year­old female with history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, EDS, POTS, cervical DDD, arthritis, fibromyalgia,
bulimia/anorexia, rheumatoid arthritis, polyarthralgia rheumatica, PTSD, psoriatic arthritis. She is following at UNC for thoracic outlet
obstruction with significant right shoulder pain.
She has been referred for MCAS. She has a myriad of symptoms and is undergoing evaluation for EDS, POTS, MCAS. My goal with
evaluation is to determine if she has systemic mastocytosis as contributing to her symptoms as a primary bone marrow disorder or if the
MCAS is secondary/reactive. We turned our discussion toward work​up of systemic mastocytosis. In systemic mastocytosis, tryptase
level is > 20, 70% of the time. There can be indolent and smoldering systemic mastocytosis. Signs and symptoms attributed to acute
and/or chronic mast cell mediator release or organ infiltration include flushing, pruritis, urticaria, usually with diffuse skin involvement. We
can also see nausea, vomiting, bloating, chronic diarrhea, GERD, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and fibromyalgia like diffuse MSK pain,
pain in long bones, osteopenia/osteoporosis, and pathologic fractures. From a Cardiovascular perspective, we can see hypotension,
tachycardia. You may not always seen evidence or changes in CBC or peripheral blood, though typically would see eosinophilia.
We can consider a bone marrow biopsy or punch biopsy of skin lesion at the time of flare to look for c­​kit mutation and tryptase staining
on the marrow, which would confirm a mast cell process driving her symptoms.
To diagnose systemic mastocytosis:
Major criterion: Multifocal dense infiltrates of mast cells (=15 mast cells in aggregates) detected in sections of bone marrow and/or other
extracutaneous organ(s).
Minor Criteria: need 3
1. In biopsy sections of bone marrow or other extracutaneous organs, >25% of the mast cells in the infiltrate are spindle ​shaped or have
atypical morphology or >25% of all mast cells in bone marrow aspirate smears are immature or atypical.
2. Detection of an activating point mutation at codon 816 of KIT in the bone marrow, blood, or another extracutaneous organ.
3. Mast cells in bone marrow, blood, or another extracutaneous organ express CD25, with or without CD2, in addition to normal mast
cell markers.
4. Serum total tryptase is persistently >20 ng/mL, unless there is an associated myeloid neoplasm, in which case this parameter is not
valid.
At this time, continue management of MCAS as directed.

Jennifer Beth Cartrette is a 43 y.o. female with hypermobile EDS, MCAS, POTS, Graves' disease involving the right eye,
fibromyalgia, bilateral vascular TOS, cervical DDD s/p C4-C6 ACDF (8/2018), Bipolar 1, ADHD, Bullemia, high
functioning autism spectrum disorder who was referred for possible right sided cervical radiculopathy after findings of
right sided C6-C7 NFS on MRI of the neck. She does report pain in the right ACF and some numbness and tingling
along the right pinky and hypothenar wrist. Strength exam and reflexes are symmetric bilaterally. NCS/EMG (11/2025)
showed no convincing electrodiagnostic evidence of a right sided cervical radiculopathy and no evidence of neurogenic
TOS on either side. We spent a little bit of time talking about her POTS symptoms, possible toe curling dystonia and
dysautonomia, but we will come back to that at her next visit in 3 months as this visit was more focused on the right
cervical radiculopathy. She is seeing vascular for vTOS, GI for slow transit, Cardiology for possible POTS, Endo for
Graves, and Rheumatology for fibromyalgia (tried treatment for psoriatric arthritis, which did not help) and planning to
undergo GI workup and possible breast reduction surgery
Plan
--No motor root involving cervical radiculopathy or brachial plexopathy seen on todays electrodiagnostic testing
--Will talk more in depth about possibility of hypermobile EDS related POTS at next visit to see if a trial of mestinon,
midodrine, or propranolol makes any sense

The mildly reduced left LAC response does not correlate with any clinical symptoms and likely arises from a technical cause and does not represent true pathology.

There is no convincing electrodiagnostic evidence of neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome on either side, compressive mononeuropathies of the upper extremities on either side, or a right sided cervical radiculopathy.

RETURN TOS PATIENT
Patient Name: Jennifer Cartrette DOB:9/13/1982
Date of Encounter: 10/23/2025
Assessment:
Patient is a 43 y.o. female with history of right extremity pain, paresthesia, numbness,
and weakness likely consistent with neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome. Positive pec
minor and anterior scalene blocks. Greater than 45 minutes was spent with the patient
describing the etiology, pathogenesis and options of care for her problem, including a
thoracic outlet decompression.
We reviewed that prior to pursuing surgical intervention, her MCAS will need to be well
controlled and under stable therapy. Additionally, she will require Neurosurgical
evaluation for her C6-7 right neuroforaminal stenosis, which will require proper
management to maximize outcomes.
Plan:
1. She will update the clinic with the consultation with Neurosurgery/Neurology for her
neuroforaminal stenosis. Encouraged sending prior imaging before consultation.
2. Continue with MCAS management and evaluation with Hematology Oncology.
3. Trial of TOS exercises. The patient was given a brochure detailing the exercises.
4. Improve ergonomics at home and at work, including acquiring the most correct
posture to allow relief of the symptoms.
5. She has hypermobile EDS, she has not been tested for type IV EDS.
6. RTC in 6 months for assessment.
HPI: Jennifer Cartrette is a 43 y.o. female who is referred by Dr. Kennard, Timothy
Patrick, MD for the evaluation of right pain and swelling. PMH includes EDS, POTS.
Hashimoto's thyroiditis, cervical DDD, arthritis, fibromyalgia, abdominal pain, bulimia,
anorexia, RA, polyarthralgia rheumatica, PTSD and psoriatic arthritis. She has
endorsed some worsening of the RUE symptoms with more pain. She has since
established with an MCAS specialist which is currently still having flares. Notably she
has had a flare after her TOS injections causing folliculitis type reaction on the right
side. She discussed bone marrow biopsy although her provider is apprehensive to

She has not seen spine surgeon for C6-7 right neuroforaminal stenosis. She has a
